School of Materials Science and Engineering State Key Laboratory of Fine Chemicals Liaoning Province Engineering Centre of High Performance Resins Dalian University of Technology Dalian 116024 Liaoning China Graphical abstract Innovative sodium-ion capacitors were fabricated based on 3D framework carbon cathode and biomass-based carbon nanosheet anode. The all-carbon sodium-ion capacitors exhibited high energy-power densities and outstanding cycle stability. Sodium-ion capacitors (SICs) are extremely promising due to the combined merits of high energy-power characteristics and considerable price advantage. However, it is still difficult to achieve high energy-power outputs and cycle stability in a typical configuration of the metal-based battery-type anode and activated carbon capacitor-type cathode due to the kinetic mismatching. In this work, a carbon nanosheet (PSCS-600) with large interlayer spacing of 0.41 nm derived from the bio-waste pine cone shell was prepared. Besides, the covalent triazine framework derived carbon (OPDN-CTF-A) was obtained through ionothermal synthesis strategy, exhibiting beneficial hierarchical pores (0.5–6 nm) and high heteroatoms (5.6 at% N, 6.6 at% O). On this basis, the all-carbon SICs were fabricated by the integration of PSCS-600 anode and OPDN-CTF-A cathode. The device delivered high energy density 111 Wh kg−1, high power output of 14,200 W kg−1 and ultra-stable cycling life (~90.7% capacitance retention after 10,000 cycles). This work provides new ideas in fabricating carbon–carbon architectural SICs with high energy storage for practical application. Keywords All-carbon capacitor Sodium-ion storage Cycle stability Carbon Electrode design 1 Introduction Energy storage devices with the combined merits of high energy and power densities, excellent reliability and considerable price advantage have drawn widespread attentions [1,2]. In particular, hybrid ion capacitors including lithium ion capacitors (LICs), sodium ion capacitors (SICs) and potassium ion capacitor (PICs) are emerging rapidly. They can bring the energy density one-step closer towards bridging the critical battery-supercapacitor divide by utilizing the following charge storage mechanisms [3–5]: (i) For the anode, reversible (de)sodiation into the bulk and deep surface offers high energy density; (ii) for the cathode, reversible (de)adsorption of anions provides rapid kinetics and stable cycling life. By reason of the lithium (Li) resources are both limited and unevenly distributed all over the world, the alternative charge carriers are highly desired. Sodium (Na) is the first-line alternate to Li due to its low cost, wide distribution and natural advantage of abundance (2.75% vs. 0.065% on Earth) [6]. Thus, SICs have attracted increasing attentions in recent years [7]. However, Na-ions have more sluggish transmission kinetics due to their larger radius compared to Li-ions (1.02 vs. 0.76 Å) [8–10]. For example, conventional graphite exhibits a low Na storage capacity of ~ 35 mAh g−1, besides, the typical activated carbon (AC) cathodes for SICs often have a low specific capacitance of only 80 F g−1, which are far from enough for practical applications. Hence, optimization of the energy-power outputs of integrated device requires tailoring the internal structure of cathode and anode materials and adjusting their mass ratio. Up to now, SICs are still in an early state, which cannot exhibit the same cycling life and cycling stability as supercapacitor, such as only ~ 80% capacitance is retained after 5,000 cycles. It is obviously not enough for a capacitor, which may achieve tens or even hundreds of charge and discharge cycles per day. This result could be ascribed to the mismatching between the anode and cathode. Generally, SICs are fabricated by coupling an AC cathode with the metal-based anode, such as the configurations of NaBi//AC [11], transition metal oxides (TMOs)//AC [12–14], MXenes//AC [15], and transition metal sulfides (TMSs)//AC [16,17]. However, an inevitable difference is generated in structure stability between these metal-based anodes and the AC cathode, because they belong to different material systems [7,18]. The charge/discharge rate, cycle stability and reliability of devices would be influenced due to the large volume expansion and electrochemical instability of the metal-based electrodes [19]. Recently, Ding et al. reported that all-carbon electrodes are more promising for hybrid ion capacitors to achieve ultra-stable and long-term cyclability [7]. However, the synthetic process of carbon is required to support the charge storage mechanism, and rational design on pores and heteroatoms remains a challenge. Biomass waste is a category of renewable and eco-friendly material with no economic value, which has been widely used to prepare the hard carbon electrodes for Li-ion and Na-ion storage technologies [20]. The biomass-derived carbon features diverse structure with high conductivity, attributing to the generated numerous defects during the pyrolysis process [21]. Generally, the derived carbon exhibits high capacity and rapid ions diffusion kinetics as the anodes for SICs. This mainly attributed to the insertion and adsorption of Na-ions at the defects and heteroatoms between the large carbon interlayer spacing of ~ 0.38 nm, which is larger than that of traditional graphite (0.335 nm) [22]. In addition, covalent triazine frameworks (CTFs) are a class of porous organic frameworks with controllable and designable pore structure, specific surface area and abundant heteroatoms. CTFs-derived carbons are normally obtained through molecular design strategy of cyclotrimerization of nitriles at a high temperature; they are extensively researched as the adsorption-type electrodes for supercapacitors in recent years [23,24]. In our view, the CTFs-derived carbon exhibits extremely promising potential as cathode for SICs in comparison with the typical AC, while the AC exhibits closed pore structure and few heteroatoms. It is highly desired to make rational design and integration of the carbon materials based on charge storage mechanisms. In this study, we proposed a new configuration of CTFs-based cathode and biomass-based anode for fabricating carbon–carbon architectural SICs. Bio-waste pine cone shell derived carbon sheets (PSCSs) were prepared by a top-down process via pyrolysis at 300, 600, and 800 °C. The PSCS-600 has a large carbon interlayer spacing of 0.41 nm. Basing on the molecular design strategy, we synthesized activated covalent triazine-based frameworks (OPDN-CTF-A) by the bottom-up method. The OPDN-CTF-A has high specific surface area (687.4 m2 g−1), hierarchical pores (0.5–6 nm) and evenly distributed heteroatoms (5.6 at% N, 6.6 at% O). Consequently, the assembled SIC based on the PSCS-600 battery-type anode and the OPDN-CTF-A capacitor-type cathode delivers a high energy density of 111 Wh kg−1 at a power density of 86 W kg−1, and retains an energy density of 40 Wh kg−1 even at the power density of 14,200 W kg−1. Furthermore, the device achieves an outstanding capacitance retention of ~ 90.7% after 10,000 cycles within the voltage window of 1.5–4.2 V. 2 Experimental 2.1 Synthesis of the PSCSs and the OPDN-CTFs To prepare PSCSs, pine cone shells were ground and washed thoroughly with deionized water. Afterwards, the pine cone shells were firstly pre-carbonized under N2 atmosphere at 450 °C for 3 h (heating rate: 5 °C min−1). Then, the obtained product was fully mixed with the same mass of KOH and treated in N2 atmosphere at 300, 600, 800 °C for 3 h, which were labelled as PSCS-300, PSCS-600, PSCS-800, respectively. The resultant black powders were washed thoroughly with 2 M HCl and deionized water to neutral, then dried at 80 °C for 24 h. The preparation of OPDN (4,4′-(4-oxophthalazine-1,3(4H)-diyl)dibenzonitrile) was shown in our previous work [25], and the 1H NMR (Fig. S1a), the Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) (Fig. S1b), the high performance liquid chromatography (HPLC) (Fig. S1c) were used to clarify the structure of precursors. OPDN-CTF was synthesized at 600 °C through ionothermal synthesis strategy with ZnCl2 as catalysis and solvent. Typically, the precursor (400 mg, 1.15 mmol) and anhydrous ZnCl2 (782 mg, 5.75 mmol) were mixed in a glovebox and transferred into a quartz ampoule. The ampoule was evacuated by a vacuum pump, sealed, and heated at a rate of 5 °C min−1 to 600 °C and maintained for 40 h. Afterwards, the compound was ground and washed thoroughly with 2 M HCl, deionized water, and then dried under vacuum at 80 °C for 24 h. The OPDN-CTF-A was prepared by activating the mixture of OPDN-CTF and KOH (mass ratio: 1:1) at a rate of 5 °C min−1 to 600 °C for 1 h, and then washed and dried using the same procedures. 2.2 Materials characterizations 1H NMR (400 Hz) spectrum was obtained with a Brucker spectrometer at 25 °C by using tetramethyl silane as an internal standard. FT-IR spectrum was recorded with a Bruker Equinox 55 spectrometer. All samples were characterized by N2 sorption/desorption at 77 K (Micromeritics, ASAP 2020). Prior to the gas adsorption, samples were outgassed at 120 °C for 8 h under a vacuum of 10−6 Torr. To further characterize the structure, samples were observed and tested using the FE-SEM (Hitachi, SU8220), TEM (Eindhoven, The Netherlands, 120 kV), XRD (Rigaku D/Max 2400, 45 kV, 200 mA), Raman scattering (Thermo Fisher Scientific DRX) and Elemental Analyzer (Elementar, Vario EL). In addition, the chemical composition was investigated by XPS (ESCALAB 250) with an Al K α X-ray source and a base pressure of 1 × 10−9 mbar. 2.3 Electrochemical measurements The electrochemical measurements were performed using a CR2032 coin-type cell. Active material (80 wt%), polyvinylidene fluoride (10 wt%) and acetylene black (10 wt%) were mixed in N-methyl-2-pyrrolidone (NMP). The obtained mixture was coated on the Al foil for cathode and the Cu foil for anode, then dried at 80 °C in a vacuum oven for 12 h. The loading weight on the anode and cathode were controlled about 1.3 and 2 mg cm−2, respectively. The 1 M NaClO4 with ethylene carbonate, diethyl carbonate and fluoroethylene carbonate (1:1: 0.05 in vol%) was used as electrolyte, and the glass microfiber GF/D was used as separator. For half-cell, the PSCSs, OPDN-CTF and OPDN-CTF-A were used as working electrodes and the metallic Na was used as counter electrode. For SICs, the PSCS-600 and OPDN-CTF-A were discharged and charged for 10 cycles in a half cell at 0.1 A g−1, the former was used as anode and the latter was used as cathode in a mass ratio of 1:1.5. All cells assembled and disassembled inside a glove box with sub 0.1 ppm water and oxygen contents. The Land CT2001A system and Biologic VMP3 working station were used for electrochemical performance testing. The energy density E (Wh kg−1) and power density P (W kg−1) were calculated using the following equations: (1) P = Δ V × I / m (2) E = P × t / 3600 (3) Δ V = V max + V min / 2 While I (A) is the discharge current, m (kg) is based on the mass of active material on both electrodes, t (s) is the discharge time, V max (V) is the beginning voltage after the IR drop and V min (V) is the final voltage of the discharge. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Structure characterization In typical methods, the pine cone shell derived carbon was prepared through simple calcination with the help of KOH. The temperature of 300 °C, 600 °C, and 800 °C was chosen to obtain a series of carbons, which are denoted as PSCS-x, where × stands for the treatment temperature. Fig. 1 (a) displays the ionothermal synthesis process of OPDN-CTF including the trimerization of nitriles groups and the following cross-links and rearrangement reactions [26]. Moreover, OPDN-CTF-A was obtained by activating OPDN-CTF with KOH (mass ratio: 1:1) at 600 °C. The framework appears as a three-dimensional (3D) network of winding microscale cross-link with sufficient porosity and abundant internal heteroatoms connected by strong covalent bonds, which is determined by the molecular design strategy. The scanning transmission electron microscope (STEM) image and corresponding mapping images of C, N and O atoms demonstrated the evenly distributed atoms in the entire frameworks (Figs. 1f–i and S2). Next, the high-resolution TEM (HRTEM) images were investigated to explore the difference in morphology of OPDN-CTF-A and PSCS-600. It could be seen that OPDN-CTF-A displays abundant and homogeneous pores without pseudo-graphite layered structure (Fig. 1b). Besides, the carbon interlayer spacing of OPDN-CTF-A cannot be measured using the interlayer spacing pattern due to its cross-linked and porous structure (Fig. 1c). In comparison, PSCS-600 exhibits a carbon nanosheet structure with long-range disordering and short-range ordering with an average carbon interlayer spacing of ~ 0.41 nm (Fig. 1d, e) [27,28]. The scanning electron microscope (SEM) images in Fig. S3 demonstrate that a small number of pores and cracks are generated in the carbon layers of PSCS-300, which is attributed to the etching effects of KOH on the lignin and hemicellulose inside biomass materials [29]. PSCS-600 exhibits a sheet-like structure containing internal defects caused by the disappearance of layered cellulose and ash. When the temperature rises to 800 °C, the carbon interlayer collapses, destroying the pathways of Na-ions [30]. Moreover, Fig. S4 exhibits the kelp-shaped nanosheet morphology of PSCS-600, which can provide numerous interpenetrating channels for electrolytes to permeate into the electrode materials sufficiently and reduce the distance of Na-ion transport. Observed from Fig. S5, OPDN-CTF and OPDN-CTF-A have extremely dense surface, which is determined by their cross-linked network structure [23]. The X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns (Fig. 2 a) exhibit two broad diffraction peaks at about 23° and 43° in all carbon samples, which could be indexed as the (002) and (100) peak, respectively. It can be discovered that the (002) peak shifts toward a lower diffraction angle with the increasing activation temperature. The Bragg’s equation was used to calculate the average carbon interlayer spacing of PSCS-300, PSCS-600 and PSCS-800 [31–33], which are 0.37, 0.41 and 0.42 nm, respectively (Table 1 ). Noteworthy is that the carbon interlayer spacing of graphite is 0.335 nm, while the minimum carbon interlayer spacing for sodiation has been proved to be 0.37 nm [34]. Hence, the enlarged carbon interlayer spacings of PSCS-600 and PSCS-800 provide efficient paths, which are the prerequisite and foundation for the Na-ion to store in the hard carbon [35,36]. In addition, the empirical parameter R was introduced to understand the graphene arrangement inside the obtained carbon materials [37,38], which is defined as the ratio of the (002) peak intensity to the surrounding background intensity. The calculation method of empirical parameter R is shown in Fig. S6. The higher R value indicates a lower percentage of a single graphene sheet in carbon. The R values of PSCS-300, PSCS-600, and PSCS-800 are 2.6, 2.3 and 1.8, respectively. In fact, abundant graphene sheets would increase the conductivity, but their long-range ordered microstructures are detrimental to Na-ions transport. As shown in the Raman spectra (Fig. 2b), two broad vibration bands at about 1345 and 1590 cm−1 are recorded as disorder-induced D-band and in-plane vibrational G-band, respectively [39]. The integral area ratio of D- to G-band (I D/I G) is regarded as an indicator of the graphite turbidity of carbon materials [35], and the fitted results of these Raman spectra are shown in Fig. S7. The integral area ratios of I D/I G for PSCS-300, PSCS-600 and PSCS-800 are about 1.96, 1.79 and 1.58, respectively, indicating a progressively ordered carbon structure as the increasing temperature. Interestingly, the OPDN-CTF and OPDN-CTF-A carbon materials exhibit more disordered structure than the PSCSs carbon materials, which is attributed to their 3D cross-linking networks. In OPDN-CTF and OPDN-CTF-A, the condensed triazine frameworks and the benzene rings provide the D- and G-bands, which are similar to the fused aromatic cluster in disordered carbon [28]. The OPDN-CTF-A has a larger integral intensity ratio of I D/I G than OPDN-CTF (2.51 vs. 2.27), indicating the disordered condensed aromatic structure increased after introducing KOH. To further investigate the pore structure of OPDN-CTF, OPDN-CTF-A, PSCS-300, PSCS-600 and PSCS-800, the N2 adsorption and desorption isothermal analysis was conducted. The I/IV type isotherms could be found in OPDN-CTF and OPDN-CTF-A (Fig. S8a), showing a rapidly increased N2 adsorption in the low-pressure area and a typical hysteresis loop in the mid-high-pressure area. This result shows that the micropores, mesopores and cross-linked framework features are coexisted in the OPDN-CTF and OPDN-CTF-A. The specific surface areas are 827.6 and 687.4 m2 g−1 of OPDN-CTF and OPDN-CTF-A, respectively, indicating that some micropores of OPDN-CTF become larger and form mesopores due to the KOH pyrolysis. The abundant mesopores provide unobstructed paths for ions diffusion compared to the micropores, the mesopores increase the electrolyte-accessible areas and reduce the irreversible trapping of anions, thereby improving the electrochemical stability of electrode during sodiation/desodiation process [33]. Despite losing some of the specific surface area, OPDN-CTF-A exhibits a larger average pore size (2.23 nm) than that of OPDN-CTF (1.41 nm), which is beneficial to the anion-adsorption kinetics. Besides, OPDN-CTF-A shows a promising hierarchical pore structure (from 0.5 to 6 nm) (Fig. 2c), which is conducive to increase the electrolyte-accessible surface area. In SICs, the anode is the inserted sites for Na-ions, which does not require a high specific surface area [4]. Therefore, although the PSCS-600 has a low specific surface area of 63.3 m2 g−1, the affluent mesopore of 2.3 ~ 37 nm is generous for ion diffusion and charge transfer kinetics (Fig. S8b). By contrast, the micropores in PSCS-800 seem like the “dead zone” for Na-ion transport. The X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) spectra were used to investigate functionalized groups of all carbon samples (Figs. S9 and S10). The pyridinic N (N − 6), pyrrolic N (N − 5) and graphitic N (N − Q) peaks are centred at about 398.1, 400 and 401 eV, and the carbonylic O (C = O) and etheric O (C − O) are centred at about 531.2 and 533.2 eV, respectively (Figs. 2d and S11). It is worth noting that the environment of defects and heteroatoms around the graphitic carbon in OPDN-CTF and OPDN-CTF-A are different, thereby red shifting of about 0.3 eV could be observed for the N − Q bonding in OPDN-CTF-A. N − 6 is the edge N atom that contributes a π-electron to the aromatic π-system and provides an extra pseudocapacitance due to its high electron density. Similarly, C = O benefits the reversible reaction with ions to improve the capacity of electrode [40]. The CTFs-derived carbon has high functional heteroatoms compared to the biomass-derived carbon, and these heteroatoms are strongly linked inside the framework carbon to ensure the electrochemical stability during the cycling. Additionally, the heteroatoms would provide extra pseudocapacitance when used as the capacitor-type cathode of SICs. Observed from Table S1, the N − 6 reduces from 26.8% in OPDN-CTF to 22.6% in OPDN-CTF-A, while the proportion of functionalized C = O increases from 45.7% to 68.2%. With the increasing temperature from 300 °C to 800 °C, the proportion of C = O in PSCSs increases at the expense of C − O due to its higher thermal stability. The elemental analysis results show that the contents of OPDN-CTF, OPDN-CTF-A and PSCSs are 7.7 wt%, 5.9 wt%, and ~ 1.1 wt% (Table S1), respectively, and the results fit the XPS result well. 3.2 Electrochemical performance tests in half-cell To qualitatively evaluate the Na-ion storage kinetics of PSCS-600, the cyclic voltammetry (CV) curves were analyzed at different scan rates from 0.2 to 2 mV s−1 (Fig. 3 a). The relationship between i and v can be described by the mathematical equation of i = avb , where v is the scan rate, a is the constant, b is an adjustable parameter ranging from 0.5 (diffusion-controlled) to 1 (surface-controlled or capacitance). Particularly, b is closer to 1, standing for that capacitance has a larger contribution to total charge storage, while b is closer to 0.5, suggesting that diffusion-controlled dominates [41,42]. Observed from the insert in Fig. 3(a), the b value is 0.88 and 0.87 of peak A and peak B, respectively. Even the voltage is far from the peak voltage, the b values of PSCS-600 fluctuate within the range of 0.5 to 1 (Fig. S12). This finding suggests that the total capacity storage is the combination of surface- and diffusion-controlled processes. According to the power-law relationship, the specific capacity can be quantificationally divided into the capacitive (k 1 v) effects and diffusion-controlled behavior (k 2 v 1/2) as follows [21,33]: i (V) = k 1 v + k 2 v 1/2. As shown in Fig. S13, the capacitive contribution (gray region) ratio of PSCS-600 could reach 67.8% at the scan rate of 1.0 mV s−1. In addition, the contribution ratio for the other scan rates can also be determined using the same methods. The typical CV curves of PSCSs electrodes at a scan rate of 0.1 mV s−1 were compared in Fig. S14. As it can be seen, PSCS-600 has the maximal integral area, demonstrating its excellent charge-storage capability. Besides, the anodic and cathodic peaks at around 0.2 V indicate the desodiation and sodiation behavior, respectively. The CV curve of PSCS-600 has a highly symmetrical anodic and cathodic peaks, which indicates that Na-ion could reversible insert/extract inside the carbon interlayer. Therefore, PSCS-600 might exhibit excellent cycle stability because of its open pore structure and large carbon interlayer spacing. The galvanostatic charge/discharge (GC/D) curves of different cycles were performed to quantitatively describe the Na storage capacity (Fig. 3b and S15a, b). The first discharge and charge capacity of PSCS-600 are 372 and 175 mAh g−1 with a coulombic efficiency of 47%. The irreversible capacity could be attributed to the formation of the SEI film and irreversible capture of Na-ions [43–45], corresponding to the cathodic peak in the first CV curve (Figs. 3d and S15c, d). Interestingly, there is a reduction peak at 1.25 V from the beginning at the second cycle of PSCS-600, suggesting a reduction reaction between heteroatom and Na, and there is a corresponding anodic peak at 1.12 V in the reverse oxidation process [46]. Obviously, the reversible capacity of PSCS-600 (137 mAh g−1) is superior to that of PSCS-300 (114 mAh g−1) and PSCS-800 (81 mAh g−1) after 500 cycles. Observed from the degressive capacities at the current densities ranging from 0.1 to 2 A g−1 (Fig. 3c), PSCS-600 shows a highly stable specific capacity of ~ 68 mAh g−1 at the current density of 2 A g−1 compared to only 42 and 32 mAh g−1 of PSCS-300 and PSCS-800, respectively. PSCS-600 maintains the original specific capacity after 50 cycles, indicating the good reversibility after different current outputs. The cycling stability and coulombic efficiency of the PSCSs electrodes were tested at the current density of 0.1 A g−1 for 1,000 cycles (Fig. 3e). The specific capacities of PSCS-600, PSCS-300 and PSCS-800 maintain at ~ 138, 117 and 94 mAh g−1 even after 1,000 cycles, indicating the excellent Na storage capacity of PSCS-600. In addition, the coulombic efficiencies of all electrodes are approximately 100% during the cycling. Fig. 4 shows the electrochemical performance of the OPDN-CTF and OPDN-CTF-A cathodes tested at an extended voltage window (1.5–4.2 V vs. Na/Na+). The CV curves of OPDN-CTF-A and OPDN-CTF exhibit “box-like” types (Figs. 4a and S16a), which are different from the electric double layer capacitors (EDLCs) [47]. This is attributed to the abundant N, O heteroatoms and defects on or near the surface of the CTFs carbon, which provide the extra pseudocapacitance [48–50]. Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) was utilized to reveal the charge transfer characteristics. Nyquist plots consist of a semicircle at high to middle frequencies region and an inclined line at low frequency, which is associated with the ionic diffusion (Fig. 4b) [51,52]. Basing on the equivalent circuit model (Fig. 4b, inset), these points were fitted and shown in Table S2. For the OPDN-CTF-A, the value of R ct corresponds to the diameter of the semicircle, which is 11.06 ohm and lower than that of OPDN-CTF (43.52 ohm). That indicates that the OPDN-CTF-A has superior structure for ion transport and electron transfer, coming from the contribution of the open pore structure [53]. Fig. 4(c) displays the GC/D curves of OPDN-CTF-A and OPDN-CTF tested at the current densities of 0.1, 0.2, 0.5, 1, 2, 5 and 10 A g−1. These GC/D curves have certain deviation with the linear characteristics of the EDLCs due to the redox reactions of the functional groups and defects, indicating the presence of pseudocapacitance, which is consistent with the results obtained by the CV curves. The specific capacitance C (F g−1) is defined using the equation: C = i × t/ΔV, where i is the current density based on the active mass, t is discharge time. The voltage window ΔV = 4.2–1.5 − IR drop, where IR drop is the drop of voltage during the discharge process, standing for the internal resistance of materials (Fig. 4d, inset). The IR drop joins EIS to demonstrate that the OPDN-CTF has larger internal resistance than that of OPDN-CTF-A, as the abundant micropores in OPDN-CTF are unconducive to ions transport. On the basis of the above equations, the specific capacitance of OPDN-CTF-A under the current densities are 141, 119, 100, 91, 80, 70 and 67F g−1 (Fig. 4d), which is superior to the OPDN-CTF and commercial YP80F AC. The pore structure characteristics of the YP80F AC was displayed in Fig. S17. Additionally, the specific capacity of OPDN-CTF-A and OPDN-CTF were tested under the above current densities (Fig. S16b, c), which are 127, 111, 99, 85, 71, 53, 45 mAh g−1 and 92, 81, 72, 63, 56, 48, 43 mAh g−1, respectively. Fig. 4(e) displays the dependence of different current densities on the capacity of OPDN-CTF-A and the comparison with advanced carbon-based materials used as cathodes for hybrid ion devices. As we can see, the OPDN-CTF-A cathode is a relatively attractive competitor whether in Na- or Li-based systems tested at a high voltage window [55–58]. Additionally, Fig. 4(f) compares the capacitance retention and coulombic efficiency of OPDN-CTF and OPDN-CTF-A, indicating their promising potential as the cathode for long-cycle SICs. The capacitance retention of OPDN-CTF-A shows a high value of ~ 85%, while the capacitance of OPDN-CTF retains at only 76%. In addition, the coulombic efficiencies are close to 99%−100% throughout the entire cycling. 3.3 Electrochemical performance tests in SICs Fig. 5 (a) illustrates the charge storage mechanism of the PSCS-600//OPDN-CTF-A SICs fabricated in 1 M NaClO4 electrolyte. During the charge process, ClO4 − ions were trapped at defects and absorbed on N, O-rich surface of the OPDN-CTF-A cathode. For the anode, Na+ ions were absorbed at defects and inserted into carbon interlayer of the PSCS-600. Similarly, the discharge process is reversible but reverse. Before evaluating the energy storage performance of the as-obtained SICs, the OPDN-CTF-A//Na and PSCS-600//Na half-cell were assembled and performed for 10 cycles at the current density of 0.1 A g−1 to enlarge the voltage window and compensate the loss of coulombic efficiency [4,54]. The GC/D curves of OPDN-CTF-A//PSCS-600 SICs at various current densities present triangular shapes, indicating the typical capacitor-type charge storage mechanism of the SICs (Figs. 5b and S18), which was also confirmed by the CV curves. As shown in Fig. S19, the deviation from an ideal rectangular-shaped CVs is a result of a “coupling effect” between two different energy storage processes in two electrodes. According to the Eqs. (1), (2) and (3) (see electrochemical measurements), the Ragone plots of OPDN-CTF-A//PSCS-600 SICs tested between 1.5–4.2 V were displayed to show the advanced energy-power characteristics (Fig. 5c). Obviously, the SICs show excellent energy-power density of 111 Wh kg−1 at 86 W kg−1 and remain 40 Wh kg−1 even at 14,200 W kg−1, which is close to the recommended target for commercial electric vehicles (15,000 W kg−1); and the detailed energy-power density at different current densities are shown in Table S3. The symmetrical OPDN-CTF-A//OPDN-CTF-A and PSCS-600//PSCS-600 SICs were also fabricated, which show considerably inferior performance to the asymmetrical OPDN-CTF-A//PSCS-600 SICs (Fig. 5c). This is attributed to the rational design of electrode materials based on the different charge storage mechanisms of the anode and cathode. The OPDN-CTF-A//PSCS-600 SICs in the other anode/cathode mass ratios were also fabricated, such as the anode/cathode mass ratio of 1:1 (OPDN-CTF-A//PSCS-600–1:1) and 1:3 (OPDN-CTF-A//PSCS-600–3:1) (Fig. S20). The OPDN-CTF-A//PSCS-600–1:1 and OPDN-CTF-A//PSCS-600–3:1 SICs delivered the inferior energy-power characteristics compared to the OPDN-CTF-A//PSCS-600–1.5:1 SIC (Fig. S21), indicating the difference in charge-transfer kinetics at the different power output due to the kinetic mismatching of anode and cathode. In addition, the OPDN-CTF-A//PSCS-600 SICs are superior to the several hybrid ion capacitors reported previously, such as Na-TNT//AC [8], PI//PI-derived carbon (Na+) [10], V2O5@CNT//AC (Na+) [13], CNT@TiO2//CNT@AC (Li+) [32], Ni(OH)2@graphene//porous graphene [43], Li4Ti5O12//trigol-RGO (Li+) [59]. The capacitance retention of some other Li- and Na-based hybrid devices are also listed for comparison (Table S4). As shown in Fig. 5(d), the OPDN-CTF-A//PSCS-600 SIC exhibits a preeminent capacitance retention of ~ 90.7% even after 10,000 cycles tested at the current density of 10 A g−1, which is an extremely advanced value compared to the previously reported devices (Na- or Li-based systems). The coulombic efficiency remains at 98%−99% during the first 200 cycles, which may be caused by a slight mismatching in the dynamics between anode and cathode. As the cycles continue, a high coulombic efficiency of ~ 99% is achieved in OPDN-CTF-A//PSCS-600 SIC. The high energy storage performance and the outstanding cycling performance of the OPDN-CTF-A//PSCS-600 SICs could mainly be attributed to the following aspects: (i) The two-dimensional PSCS-600 exhibits large carbon interlayer spacing for the sodiation process. (2) The three-dimensional OPDN-CTF-A has large surface area, reasonable hierarchical pores and evenly distributed internal N and O heteroatoms, thus exhibiting high pseudocapacitance. (3) All-carbon electrodes architectural system makes up for the difference in kinetics and enhance the conductivity and electrochemical stability. Moreover, the OPDN-CTF-A//PSCS-600 SIC was used to light a light-emitting diode (LED) array, which contains 36 green LEDs in parallel at 2.6 V, further indicating the practical application (Fig. 5d, inset). 4 Conclusions In summary, a novel carbon–carbon architectural SIC has been fabricated by high-performance and inexpensive materials. Due to the structural and kinetic matching advantages of the two carbon materials, PSCS-600 anode and OPDN-CTF-A cathode exhibit fast sodium-ion storage kinetics and high pseudocapacitive characteristics, respectively. Ultimately, the fabricated PSCS-600//OPDN-CTF-A SICs delivered a high energy density of 111 Wh kg−1 and a high-power output of 14,200 W kg−1. Importantly, the PSCS-600//OPDN-CTF-A SICs exhibited outstanding cycle stability of ~ 90.7% after 10,000 cycles, which is outperform or at least comparable to the current state-of-the-art hybrid ion capacitors. As the eco-friendly, light-weight and high-performance energy storage devices, all-carbon SICs have great potential for practical applications in the future. coredata.dc:description: Sodium-ion capacitors (SICs) are extremely promising due to the combined merits of high energy-power characteristics and considerable price advantage. However, it is still difficult to achieve high energy-power outputs and cycle stability in a typical configuration of the metal-based battery-type anode and activated carbon capacitor-type cathode due to the kinetic mismatching. In this work, a carbon nanosheet (PSCS-600) with large interlayer spacing of 0.41 nm derived from the bio-waste pine cone shell was prepared. Besides, the covalent triazine framework derived carbon (OPDN-CTF-A) was obtained through ionothermal synthesis strategy, exhibiting beneficial hierarchical pores (0.5–6 nm) and high heteroatoms (5.6 at% N, 6.6 at% O). On this basis, the all-carbon SICs were fabricated by the integration of PSCS-600 anode and OPDN-CTF-A cathode. The device delivered high energy density 111 Wh kg−1, high power output of 14,200 W kg−1 and ultra-stable cycling life (~90.7% capacitance retention after 10,000 cycles). This work provides new ideas in fabricating carbon–carbon architectural SICs with high energy storage for practical application.

coredata.dc:title: High and ultra-stable energy storage from all-carbon sodium-ion capacitor with 3D framework carbon as cathode and carbon nanosheet as anode
